title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology, Part A
abstract: Climate changes due to global warming result in part from the release of gases such as carbon dioxide (CO 2) and methane into the atmosphere and results in warming and acidification of water bodies, and changes precipitation and wind patterns, which might in turn affect water currents, turbulence and turbidity. These changes might affect feeding and its endocrine control. Feeding is regulated by central and peripheral hormones that either stimulate (e.g. orexin, ghrelin) or inhibit (e.g. irisin, cocaine and amphetamine regulated transcript-CART, cholecystokinin-CCK and peptide YY-PYY) food intake. In this study we examined the effects of four climate change-related environmental factors (i.e. temperature, pH, turbulence and turbidity) on food intake and the hypothalamic and intestinal expressions of appetite regulators in fish, using goldfish as a model. High temperatures increased food intake and the brain expression of orexin, and decrease brain CART 1 and intestinal CCK, PYY and ghrelin. Low pHs decreased feeding and increased the expressions of CART1 and CART2 in the hypothalamus and CCK and PYY in the intestine. Turbulence (waves) induced an increase in food intake and a decrease in mRNA expression levels of both CART1 and CART2 in the hypothalamus and both CCK and PYY in the intestine. Turbidity (low visibility) did not affect food intake but increased locomotion and the time taken to reach satiation, while increasing brain orexin and intestinal PYY expression levels and lowering CART1 hypothalamic expression. The results of this study suggest that environmental stress affects feeding physiology of goldfish and bring new insights on how fish might respond to climate changes.

abstract.text: Climate changes due to global warming result in part from the release of gases such as carbon dioxide (CO 2) and methane into the atmosphere and results in warming and acidification of water bodies, and changes precipitation and wind patterns, which might in turn affect water currents, turbulence and turbidity. body_text.text: Food intake is regulated by hormones produced by both brain and peripheral tissues that affect feeding centers in the brain to either stimulate or inhibit feeding (Volkoff, 2016) . Orexin and CART (cocaine and amphetamine regulated transcript) are key factors produced mainly by the brain that stimulate and inhibit the desire to eat in fish, respectively. CCK (cholecystokinin) and PYY (peptide YY), which act as satiety factors, and ghrelin, which stimulates appetite, are produced mainly by the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) (Volkoff, 2016; Ronnestad et al., 2017) .

Climate changes due to global warming result in part from the release of gases such as carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and methane into the atmosphere (Danladi Bello et al., 2017) . The increase in atmospheric CO 2 results in warming and acidification of rivers and oceans, and could potentially change precipitation and wind patterns, which might in turn affect water currents and salinities. All these changes might affect many aspects of fish physiology and behavior, including feeding and its endocrine control (Bernier, 2010; Ahmed et al., 2019; Volkoff, 2019) .

Being ectothermic, fish are very sensitive to changes in water temperature. Increases in water temperatures increase oxygen consumption and metabolic rates and thus energy requirements (Sandblom et al., 2014) . Although changes are species-specific, in fish, food intake usually increases with moderate temperature increases [e.g. coral trout Plectropomus leopardus (Scott et al., 2017) ; major carp Catla catla (Sharma et al., 2017) ]. A few studies have reported that these changes in feeding are correlated with changes in some appetite-regulating endocrine factors [e.g. changes in plasma concentrations of ghrelin (Hevrøy et al., 2012; Vikeså et al., 2017) and leptin (Kullgren et al., 2013) in Atlantic salmon Salmo salar; CART expression in Atlantic cod Gadus morhua (Kehoe and Volkoff, 2008) ]. However, overall, very little is known about the effects of temperature changes on appetite-regulating systems of fish.

In the marine environment, atmospheric CO enters the seawater, resulting in a decrease in pH through the production of carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ) (Hasler et al., 2016) . In freshwater, dissolved CO 2 levels vary widely and are controlled not only by dissolution of atmospheric CO 2 but also by other factors, such as water source, geology of a water body and resident ecosystems (Hasler et al., 2016) . Studies have shown that increases in CO 2 and low pH reduce food intake in fish [e.g. seabass Dicentrarchus labrax (Cecchini et al., 2001) ] and impair their olfactory senses, thus decreasing the ability of fish to detect chemical signals and food (Leduc et al., 2013; Jiahuan et al., 2018; Porteus et al., 2018) . However, there is no published report on the possible involvement of appetite regulators in these changes.
The increasing frequency and intensity of storms and cyclones due https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cbpa.2019.06.001

to climate changes might lead to higher winds and larger oceanic tides, and disturbances of currents in oceans, rivers and freshwater bodies (e.g. lakes and ponds) (Johansen, 2014; Johansen et al., 2015) . These water movements might affect foraging and feeding activity in fish. Turbulent waters have been shown to increase energy intake in fish, as animals need more muscle work to keep their balance and to sustain swimming efforts (Liao and Cotel, 2013; Muhawenimana et al., 2018) . Increases in turbulence, along with changing precipitation patterns (Trenberth, 2011) that increase the amounts of sediment into rivers, lakes and coastal zones (Ashmore and Church, 2000) , might also result in increases in turbidity due to an increase in the amount of suspended particles, creating low visibility conditions, thus influencing feeding in fish (Borner et al., 2015; Potts et al., 2015) , in particular visual predators (Suursaar et al., 2015) . To our knowledge, there is no published data on the effects of turbulence and turbidity on endocrine mechanisms regulating feeding in fish.

The objectives of this study were to examine the effects of four climate change-related environmental factors (i.e. temperature, pH, turbulence and turbidity) on food intake and the brain and intestine expression of appetite regulators in fish, using goldfish as a model. The results of this study bring new insights on how fish might respond to climate changes.

Fish were purchased from MSR Imporium Importations Canada (Lasalle, QC, Canada) and kept under a simulated photoperiod of 12 h light: 12 h dark in 65 L tanks, with constantly aerated and filtered water at 18°C (pH 6.8). The air temperature in the fish room was maintained at 18°C and water temperatures in the fish tanks were the same as the air temperature in the room.

The sides of the tanks were opaque to minimize external disturbances. Fish were fed to satiety once a day (10:00) with goldfish (33% protein, 8% fat, 2% fiber, 8.5% moisture, 8% ash, Omega Sea, Sitka, Alaska, USA) sinking pellets. Fish were acclimated under these conditions for 2 weeks before the start of an experiment. Both males and females were used. All experiments were carried out in accordance with the principles published in the Canadian Council on Animal Care's guide to the care and use of experimental animals (MUN protocol # 17-08-HV).

Fish (average weight 16.8 ± 0.9 g; average total length 12.0 ± 0.4 cm) were transferred to six 20 L aquaria (5 fish per tank). Room temperature was gradually adjusted to 15°C over a week using an air conditioning unit. Temperature was maintained at 15°C in two tanks and gradually adjusted over a period of 2 weeks to 25°C and 35°C in the other two sets of duplicate tanks, respectively. Temperatures of 25°C and 35°C were adjusted with submersible water heaters (Hagen, Baie d'Urfé, QC, Canada) and checked daily. Water temperature was monitored daily with a digital thermometer (model PH100, Dr. meter, www.drmeter.com). Once all water temperatures were stabilized, fish were exposed to these temperatures for 2 weeks and food intake was quantified daily. At the end of the experiment, four fish per tank (n = 8 per group) were sampled for brain and intestine.

After acclimation at 18°C, fish (average weight 14 ± 0.6 g; average total length 10.8 ± 0.2 cm) were transferred to continuously aerated L tanks (5 fish per tank). The pH in the tanks was then gradually adjusted (over 2 weeks) to a desired pH with 0.1 N H 3 PO 4 or 0.1 N NaOH. Two tanks were adjusted to pH 7.5, two to pH 6.5 and two to pH 5.5 (Chen et al., 2014) . Water pH was checked daily measured with a portable pH meter (model PH100, Dr. meter, www.drmeter.com) and adjusted if necessary with H PO 4 or NaOH (Bolner et al., 2014) . Once pHs were established in the tanks, fish were subjected to these conditions for 2 weeks and food intake was quantified daily. At the end of the experiment, four fish per tank (n = 8 per group) fish were sampled for brain and intestine.

Fish (average weight 12.2 ± 0.6 g; average total length 9.9 ± 0.2 cm) were transferred to four 20 L aquaria (5 fish per tank). Two of the tanks had a commercial wave maker (Power Sweep 212, 125 GPH, Zoo Med Laboratories, Obispo, CA, USA), which created a gentle turbulence of the water. Fish submitted to waves were still able to swim and feed. Fish were acclimated under these conditions for 2 weeks, time at which the experiment started. Fish were then submitted to turbulence (or no turbulence for control fish) for 2 weeks, during which food intake was quantified daily. At the end of the experiment, four fish per tank (n = 8 per group) were sampled for brain and intestine.

Fish (average weight 14.4 ± 0.6 g; average total length 10.3 ± 0.2 cm) were transferred to six 20 L aquaria (5 fish per tank). To determine the effects of turbidity on feeding, a blue pond dye (Pond Logic Twilight Blue, Airmax Inc., Romeo, MI, USA) was added to tanks at 0 (control),~100 μl and~200 μl (Bristow et al., 1996; Clayton et al., 2009) . Visibility was assessed by spectrophotometry (Genesys10S, Thermo Scientific, Lafayette, CO, USA) at 660 nm (blue peak absorption) (100, 96, 92% transmittance; 0; 0.02, 0.04 absorbance). Fish were acclimated under these conditions for 2 weeks, time at which the experiment started. Food intake was quantified daily for 2 weeks. Fish were trained to feed in the front of the tank, so that they could be easily seen in the tanks with darker water, and satiety could be observed. At the end of the two-week experiment, four fish per tank (n = 8 per group) were sampled for brain and intestine.

Fish were fed to satiety once daily (10:00) till apparent satiation. Fish were fed slowly and carefully by hand with several rounds of pellets to ensure that all pellets added to the tank were consumed. Satiation was defined as the moment when fish stopped searching for and consuming pellets. The total weight of pellets given to each tank was recorded. Average daily food intake (g food/g fish) per tank was calculated by dividing the average amount of food consumed by the average weigh of fish and the number of fish per tank (5).

Fish were deeply anaesthetized by immersion in 0.05% tricaine methanesulfonate (TMS) (Syndel Laboratories, Vancouver, BC, Canada), killed by spinal section and sampled. Whole brains and intestines (proximal) were dissected and immediately placed on ice in RNAlater (Qiagen, Mississauga, ON, Canada) and stored at −20°C until RNA extractions were performed. Hypothalami [one of the major brain area regulating feeding in fish (Cerdá-Reverter and Canosa, 2009; Ronnestad et al., 2017) ] were subsequently dissected from whole brains. Proximal intestine was chosen as this is the region of the intestine where most digestion/absorption take place and where appetiteregulating hormone-secreting cells are located (Jönsson and Holmgren, 2011).

Total RNA was isolated with a GeneJET™ RNA Purification Kit (Fermentas, Burlington, ON, Canada) following the manufacturer's protocol. Final RNA concentrations were determined by optical density reading at 260 nm using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (NanoDrop Technologies Inc., Wilmington, USA). The quality of RNA samples was assessed by gel electrophoresis and by measuring the ratio of sample absorbance at 260 and 280 nm. Only RNA samples with a ratio between 1.8 and 2.1 were used.

One microgram of total RNA was reverse transcribed to cDNA, using a Verso cDNA synthesis Kit (Thermo Scientific, Lafayette, CO, USA), which includes an RT Enhancer that prevents residual genomic DNA, using a mix of anchored oligo-dT and primer random hexamers, according to the manufacturer's protocol.

Duplicate reactions were prepared containing 5 μl Sso Advanced Universal SYBR Green Supermix (BioRad, Hercules, CA, USA), 0.5 μl water, 0.25 μl 10 μM forward primer, 0.25 μl 10 μM reverse primer, and 4 μl cDNA (diluted 1:3 with water). The total reaction volume (10 μl) was then loaded into a 96-well plate with an epMotion® 5070 automated pipetting system (Eppendorf, Mississauga, ON, Canada). The cDNA was amplified using specific primers designed based on cloned sequences using Primer 3 software (http://primer3.sourceforge.net) (Table 1 ) in a CFX96 Touch Real-Time PCR Detection System (BioRad) and the cycle: denaturation (95°C for 3 min), followed by 40 cycles of denaturation (95°C for 10 s), annealing (58°C for 10 s), elongation (72°C for 10 s). Before experimental data analyses, efficiencies, R 2 values, and optimal annealing temperatures were determined for all primer pairs. Efficiencies ranged from 90 to 100% for all reactions. A melting curve analysis was also performed at the end of each qPCR to verify primer specificity. 18S, β-actin, elongation factor α-1 were tested for use as reference genes using NormFinder Software (https://moma. dk/normfinder-software). For all experiments, β-actin was the most stable reference gene across all groups in both intestine and hypothalamus. For most experimental groups, the number of samples is 8, but this number ranged from 6 to 8, as some samples did not have enough RNA following extractions.

All statistical tests were performed using InStat 3.0 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA). Significance was considered at p < .05. Data are expressed as mean ± SEM. Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests were used to determine if data followed a normal distribution. Daily food intake followed a normal distribution and was compared using either Student's t-tests (two groups, turbulence experiment) or ANOVA followed by Tukey's post test (three groups, temperature, pH and turbidity experiments). For gene expression, all samples are expressed as ratios of specific target gene to the reference gene and normalized as a percentage of mRNA levels of fish in the control groups (set at 100%). As not all data followed a normal distribution, statistical differences between treatment groups were assessed using non-parametric Mann-Whitney tests (for two groups in the turbulence experiment) and Kluskal-Wallis test followed by Dunn's multiple comparison tests (for three groups in temperature, pH and turbidity experiments).
Fish held at 25°C and 35°C had higher food intake than fish held at 15°C. There were no significant differences between fish held at 25°C and fish held at 35°C (Fig. 1) .

body_text.section: Effects of environmental factors on food intake

body_text.text: In the hypothalamus, fish held at 35°C had higher orexin expression than fish held at 15°C ( Fig. 2A) . Fish held at 25°C and 35°C had lower expression levels of CART1 compared to fish held at 15°C ( Fig. 2A ). There were no differences in either irisin or CART2 expressions between groups ( Fig. 2A) .

In the intestine, fish held at 35°C and 25°C had lower brain expression levels of CCK and PYY compared to fish held at 15°C (Fig. 2B) . Fish held at 35°C had lower brain expression levels of ghrelin compared to fish held at 15°C (Fig. 2B) .

Fish held at pH 5.5 had higher brain expression of CART1 and CART2 compared to fish held at pH 7.5. There were no differences in either orexin or irisin expressions between groups (Fig. 3A) . In the intestine, fish held at pH 5.5 and pH 6.5 had higher brain expression of PYY compared to fish held at pH 7.5 and fish held at pH 5.5 had higher brain expression of CCK compared to fish held at pH 7.5 ( Fig. 3B ). There were no differences in ghrelin expression between groups (Fig. 3B) .

Compared to control fish, fish submitted to waves had lower mRNA expression levels of both CART1 and CART2 in the hypothalamus (Fig. 4A ) and both CCK and PYY in the intestine (Fig. 4B) . Turbulence had no significant effects on the hypothalamic expressions of either brain orexin or intestine ghrelin.

Compared to control fish, fish submitted to low and high turbidity had higher orexin mRNA expression levels and higher CART1 mRNA expression levels in the hypothalamus (Fig. 5A ). There were no Table 1 Sequences of primers used for gene expression studies.

differences in either NPY or CART2 hypothalamic expressions between groups (Fig. 5A ).

In the intestine, fish held at low and high turbidity had higher brain expression of PYY compared to control fish (Fig. 5B ). There were no differences in either CCK or ghrelin expression between groups (Fig. 5B ).

In our study fish held at higher temperatures (25°C and 35°C) had higher food intake than fish held at 15°C. Similar to our results, goldfish acclimated for 4 weeks at 24 and 28°C have higher foraging activity and food consumption than fish acclimated at 15°C (Chen et al., 2019) . This increase in feeding in goldfish is not surprising as other fish species have been shown to increase consumption with moderate temperature increases [e.g. freshwater fish such as common carp Cyprinus carpio (Song-bo et al., 2012) , major carp Catla catla (Sharma et al., 2017) , channel catfish (Buentello et al., 2000) , walking catfish Clarias batrachus (Ahmad et al., 2014) , striped catfish Pangasianodon hypophthalmus (Islam et al., 2019) ; marine fish such as Atlantic salmon Salmo salar (Folkedal et al., 2012) , coral trout Plectropomus leopardus (Scott et al., 2017) , damselfish Abudefduf vaigiensis (Rowe et al., 2018) , greater amberjack Seriola dumerili (Fernández-Montero et al., 2018)], likely due to increased oxygen consumption and metabolic rates at higher temperatures (Sandblom et al., 2014) . Interestingly, the taste system and food perception of fish are also affected by water temperature, a response that might be important in coping with seasonal shifts in diet and food availability (Kasumyan, 2019) . It must be noted that there is great species-specific variation, depending on the optimal/ lethal temperature values [for example, in seahorses Hippocampus guttulatus, individuals at 18, 26 or 28 and 30°C have similar food intake (Aurélio et al., 2013) ] and that goldfish have a wide range of temperature tolerances compared with other fish species (Cockrem et al., 2019) .

Very few studies have examined the role of endocrine factors in temperature-induced changes in food intake in fish. In our study, fish held at higher temperatures had higher orexin expression (35°C only) and lower CART1 expression (25 and 35°C) in the hypothalamus. Similar to our results, goldfish held at 28°C have been shown to have higher hypothalamic orexin expression and lower telencephalon (but not hypothalamic) CART1 expression than fish at 15°C (Chen et al., 2019) . Also, consistent with our data, Atlantic cod, acclimated at 11°C and 15°C have higher food intake and lower CART brain mRNA levels compared to fish acclimated to 2°C (Kehoe and Volkoff, 2008) . However, in spotted halibut, Verasper variegatus, there were no differences in orexin brain expression between 12, 15, 18, and 21°C (Shimizu et al., 2019) .

In the intestine, fish held at higher temperatures had lower transcript expression levels of CCK, PYY (35°C and 25°C) and ghrelin (35°C only) compared to fish held at 15°C. To our knowledge, there is no available data on the effects of temperature on the intestinal expression of these peptides in fish. However, in goldfish, lower CCK expression levels are seen in the hypothalamus at 28°C compared to 15°C (Chen et al., 2019) . The decrease in CCK and PYY in fish at higher temperature, suggest that these peripheral peptides might in part mediate the increase in feeding. However in seahorse Hippocampus erectus, there were no significant changes in CCK brain expression between 22°C and 26°C (Zhang et al., 2018 ), suggesting major inter-specific differences.

Fish held at 35°C had lower intestine expression levels of ghrelin compared to fish held at 15°C. In contrast to our results, in chinese perch Siniperca chuatsi, stomach ghrelin mRNA expression is higher at 26°C and 32°C than at 18°C (Song et al., 2017) . In Atlantic salmon, no significant differences in plasma ghrelin levels are seen at different temperatures (Jönsson, 2013; Kullgren et al., 2013; Vikeså et al., 2015) .

In our study, fish held at pH 6.5 and pH 5.5 both had lower food intake than fish held at a neutral pH 7.5. Our results are consistent with previous studies showing that increases in CO 2 accompanied by low pHs reduce food intake and feeding behavior in several fish, including freshwater [e.g. pikeperch Sander lucioperca (Steinberg et al., 2017)] and marine species [e.g. seabass Dicentrarchus labrax (Cecchini et al., 2001 ), Atlantic salmon (Haya et al., 1985; Lacroix and Townsend, 1987) , kingfish Seriola lalandi (Abbink et al., 2012) , Port Jackson sharks Heterodontus portusjacksoni (Pistevos et al., 2017) ].

Exposure to elevated CO 2 can also impair swimming performance [e.g. largemouth bass Micropterus salmoides (Schneider et al., 2019) , lesser-spotted catshark Scyliorhinus canicula (Rosa et al., 2017) , bighead carp Hypophthalmichthys nobilis (Cupp et al., 2016) ] thus affecting feeding behaviors.

Changes in pCO 2 and pH can also affect fish sensory systems and anti-predator responses (Leduc et al., 2013; Draper and Weissburg, 2019) , as they can impair visual and olfactory functions in teleost fish and might result in decreases in feeding and escape behaviors (Domenici et al., 2007; McCormick and Levin, 2017) [e.g. black sea bream, Acanthopagrus schlegelii (Jiahuan et al., 2018) , fathead minnow Pimephales promelas (Dennis Lemly and Smith, 1985) In addition, low pH waters can shift fish taste preferences, perhaps by modifying palatability of different foods (Kasumyan and Døving, 2003) .

Species-specific differences in response have been shown among fish as some fish are more resilient to changes in CO 2 and pH (Heuer and Grosell, 2014) . For example, high CO 2 levels do not alter the behavior of either the benthic reef-dwelling epaulette shark Hemiscyllium ocellatum (Heinrich et al., 2016) , silver carp Hypophthalmichthys molitrix (Tix et al., 2017) , Atlantic cod (Jutfelt and Hedgärde, 2013) , or goldsinny wrasse Ctenolabrus rupestris (Sundin and Jutfelt, 2016) . These species-specific differences might be due in part to an adaptation to low environmental oxygen conditions and normal diel fluctuations in CO 2 encountered in some fish habitats (Heinrich et al., 2016) .

High CO 2 levels also affects digestive processes. In Atlantic cod, exposure to high CO 2 levels prolongs the time for digestion and decreases digestive efficiency (Tirsgaard et al., 2015) and in toadfish Opsanus beta, CO 2 exposure causes an increase of intestinal HCO 3secretion and affect digestive functions (Heuer and Grosell, 2016) .

To our knowledge there are no published studies on the effects of pH on appetite regulators. In our study, fish held at lower pHs had higher brain expression of CART1 and CART2 and higher intestinal expressions of CCK and PYY compared to fish held at pH 7.5, suggesting that low pHs might affect feeding behavior in part via increases in central and peripheral anorexigenic peptides. In addition, changes in intestinal CCK and PYY expressions likely cause changes in the digestive functions of fish, perhaps affecting digestion and absorption of nutrients.

In our study, fish submitted to turbulence (waves) displayed higher food intake than control fish. Consistent with our results, in southern catfish Silurus meridionalis (Li et al., 2016) and qingbo Spinibarbus sinensis (Li et al., 2013) , long-term mild execrcise increases food intake and in juvenile Chinese sturgeon, Acipenser sinensis, food consumption increases as water current speed increases (Gu et al., 2018) . Similarly, in larval seahorses Hippocampus erectus, fish submitted to low continuous currents have similar but slightly higher food intake than control fish (Qin et al., 2014) . This increase in feeding is likely needed to counterbalance the energy expenditure needed to sustain swimming efforts. However, in Pacific bluefin tuna Thunnus orientalis, feeding rates decrease at higher turbulence levels (Kato et al., 2008) , and in larval Atlantic cod, prey hunting success (thus feeding rates) decreases as turbulence increases (MacKenzie and KiØrboe, 2000) . These differences are likely due to the differences in habitats that exist among species, as some fish use high speed swimming in fast flowing water (e.g. tuna, salmon, cod), whereas others (e.g. cyprinids such as goldfish, carp and qingbo, as well as catfish) live in relatively still waters and cannot handle high currents.

In our study, turbulence decreased the mRNA expression levels of CART1 and CART2 in the hypothalamus and both CCK and PYY in the intestine but did not affect brain orexin or irisin and intestine ghrelin. The decrease in the expression of central and peripheral appetite-inhibiting factors might indicate that the increase in feeding is mediated by partial inhibition of anorexigenic systems. To our knowledge, there are no published studies on the effects of turbulence on appetite regulators.

There were no significant effects of turbidity on food intake in our study. A decrease in feeding rates in high turbidity has been reported for some carnivorous visual predatory fish species, such as bluegill Lepomis macrochirus (Gardner, 1981) , cape silverside Atherina breviceps (Hecht and van der Lingen, 1992) , delta smelt Hypomesus transpacificus (Geist et al., 2013) and three-spined stickleback Gasterosteus aculeatus (Sohel et al., 2017) , spiny damselfish Acanthochromis polyacanthus (Leahy et al., 2011) , and pinfish Lagodon rhomboides (Lunt and Smee, 2015) . However, in the planktivorous fish such as black crappy Pomoxis nigromaculatus and juvenile yellow perch Perca flavescens (Wellington et al., 2010) , turbidity does not affect food consumption. In addition, as seen in our study (as seen by an increase in the time taken to reach satiation), high turbidity induces a more active foraging in black crappy (Andree and Wahl, 2019) . It is likely that goldfish use senses other than vision to find food. Indeed, as opposed to carnivorous predator fish, which use almost solely vision to capture their preys, omnivorous fish such as catfish and carp Cyprinus carpio and goldfish, in addition to vision, use the taste and olfactory systems to excite and discriminate chemical stimuli. In addition, carp and goldfish have taste-controlled reflex snapping/biting mechanisms and use oral food sorting to separate edible from inedible objects (Valentinčič, 2004) . In the wild, goldfish actually increase turbidity as a consequence of their suck/pit mode of feeding: they suck up mouthful of sediments which is then spat out forming a cloud of suspended sediment from which they pick any edible portion (Richardson et al., 1995) .

Compared to control fish, fish submitted to turbidity took longer to reach satiation and remained active (foraging) for longer periods than control fish. Although this was not quantified, it took 2-3 rounds of feeding for controls but 4-6 for high turbidity, suggesting they had more difficulty finding food and spent more time and energy looking for food. The increased expressions of orexin and CART in the brain of both turbidity groups are likely related to this hyperlocomotion, as both peptides have been shown to increase locomotion and activity in goldfish (Volkoff et al., 1999; Volkoff, 2013; Nakamachi et al., 2014) .

The increase in PYY seen in experimental fish compared to control fish might be due to a later surge of PYY in turbid/dyed water, as they took longer to reach satiation. Indeed, it is possible that PYY levels in control fish that had eaten faster and earlier than fish in turbid water, had already returned to basal levels by the time of sampling. For example, in Atlantic salmon, whereas brain expression levels CCK levels remain high up to 12 h post-feeding, the peak in PYY expression is relatively short-lived, as a short peak in PYY is seen only around 3 h post feeding before decreasing (Valen et al., 2011) .

There is also evidence in mammals that PYY increases locomotor and exploratory behaviors. In rodents, where PYY knockouts have the same food intake as control animals, they have lower exploratory/ingestive behavior levels (Edelsbrunner et al., 2009) . This could suggest that an increase in PYY expression levels in fish in turbid waters might be in part responsible for their increase in locomotion.

In summary, our study shows that temperature, pH, turbulence and turbidity can affect food intake/feeding behavior and the expressions of appetite-regulating peptides in goldfish (Suppl. Fig. 1 ). Increased temperature seemed to be the factor that most affected feeding and gene expression, whereas turbidity was the least disturbing factor. Increasing either temperature or waves increased food intake, in part by downregulating mRNA transcripts of anorexigenic hormones, whereas decreasing pH had the opposite effect. The brain anorexigenic CART system, in particular CART1, and the intestinal satiety factors CCK and PYY seemed to be the most affected genes, whereas little or no changes were seen for brain orexin and intestinal ghrelin, suggesting that anorexigenic appetite regulators might be more sensitive to changes in environmental factors than appetite stimulators. Interestingly, irisin was not affected by any of the environmental challenges, although it has been previously shown to affect feeding in goldfish (Butt et al., 2017) . However, the role of irisin is still unclear and further studies are needed to determine its role on feeding and metabolism in fish. Irisin being an exercise-induced myokine in mammals (Cao et al., 2019) , it is also possible that changes in irisin expression might have been seen in the skeletal muscle.

It must be kept in mind that these effects appear to be largely species-specific and depend on experimental conditions. Goldfish are extremely tolerant of environmental stress, being able to survive in wide ranges of temperatures, turbidity, salinity and pH, can cope with water pollution, low levels of dissolved oxygen and changes in their omnivorous diet (Lorenzoni et al., 2007) . This allows them to live in a wide variety of habitats (Lorenzoni et al., 2007) . One must thus not generalize these results to all fish, and studies examining the effects of environmental factors on several other fish species, perhaps less resistant than goldfish, might bring new insights on the effects of climate changes on the feeding physiology of fish.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.cbpa.2019.06.001.
